title: The Divisions of Faith
introduction: Chapter 17 of the Bhagavad Gita, Śraddhātraya-vibhāga-yoga (The Yoga of the Division of the Three Kinds of Faith), is one of the most psychologically penetrating and immediately applicable chapters in the entire scripture. After describing the divine and demonic natures (Ch. 16), Arjuna now asks a very practical follow-up: people who disregard scripture yet worship with great faith — which guna (mode of nature) governs their faith, sacrifice, food, austerity, and charity? Krishna answers by classifying every aspect of human life — faith, food, sacrifice, austerity, charity, even the syllable OM — according to the three gunas. For modern readers — especially those navigating wellness culture, spiritual-but-not-religious trends, diet fads, performative activism, self-optimization routines, and the question 'is my practice actually helping or just feeding ego?' — this chapter feels like a brutally honest audit tool. Krishna explains why two people can do the 'same' yoga/meditation/veganism/charity and get opposite results: one purifies and elevates (sattvic), one binds and degrades (rajasic or tamasic). The essence remains perfectly preserved: faith is never neutral — it is always colored by one of the three gunas; true spiritual progress depends not just on what you do, but on the quality (sattva-dominant) of the inner attitude and intention behind it; the highest practice is offered to the Supreme Person with the syllable OM and full surrender.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अर्जुन उवाच |
ये शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः |
तेषां निष्ठा तु का कृष्ण सत्त्वमाहो रजस्तमः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca
ye śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ
teṣāṁ niṣṭhā tu kā kṛṣṇa sattvam āho rajas tamaḥ
shlokas.translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, what is the situation of those who do not follow the principles of scripture but worship according to their imaginations? Are they in the mode of goodness, passion or ignorance?
shlokas.modern: Arjuna asks the most relevant question for our time: people who ignore scripture yet worship with strong faith — which guna rules their faith? In 2026 life this covers almost everyone — 'spiritual but not religious', self-made rituals, manifestation culture, eclectic new-age practices, intense but unscriptural sadhana. Arjuna is not judging — he wants clarity: does sincerity alone suffice, or does the quality (guna) of faith matter? Krishna’s answer will be precise and uncompromising.

shlokas.sanskrit:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
त्रिविधा भवति श्रद्धा देहिनां सा स्वभावजा |
सात्त्विकी राजसी चैव तामसी चेति तां शृणु ||
shlokas.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
tri-vidhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṁ sā svabhāva-jā
sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṁ śṛṇu
shlokas.translation: The Supreme Personality of Godhead said: According to the modes of nature acquired by the embodied soul, there are three kinds of faith — in goodness, passion and ignorance. Now hear about these.
shlokas.modern: Krishna answers directly: faith is threefold — sattvic, rajasic, tamasic — born of one’s acquired nature (svabhāva). In practice: no one’s faith is 'neutral' or 'purely personal' — it is always conditioned by the dominant guna. This verse is foundational — faith is not exempt from the gunas; it is shaped by them. Krishna is about to classify every visible aspect of spiritual life by these three lenses.

shlokas.sanskrit:
सत्त्वानुरूपा सर्वस्य श्रद्धा भवति भारत |
श्रद्धामयोऽयं पुरुषो यो यच्छ्रद्धः स एव सः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata
śraddhā-mayo ’yaṁ puruṣo yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ
shlokas.translation: O son of Bharata, the faith of each is in accordance with his own nature. A man consists of his faith; as a man’s faith is, so is he.
shlokas.modern: Everyone’s faith matches their inner constitution (sattva). A person is made of his faith — as is his faith, so he becomes. This is one of the most quoted and consequential verses in the Gita. In 2026 terms: you literally become what you deeply trust and invest belief in. Faith is not abstract — it is identity-forming. Krishna is saying: look at what you have faith in (God, money, status, self, nothing) — that is shaping who you are becoming. This verse is both diagnostic and cautionary — choose the object of faith wisely.

shlokas.sanskrit:
यजन्ते सात्त्विका देवान् यक्षरक्षांसि राजसाः |
प्रेतान्भूतगणांश्चान्ये यजन्ते तामसा जनाः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
yajante sāttvikā devān yakṣa-rakṣāṁsi rājasāḥ
pretān bhūta-gaṇāṁś cānye yajante tāmasā janāḥ
shlokas.translation: Men in the mode of goodness worship the demigods; those in the mode of passion worship demons; those in the mode of ignorance worship ghosts and spirits.
shlokas.modern: Sattvic people worship devas (higher divine beings); rajasic worship yakshas/rakshasas (power-seeking entities); tamasic worship pretas/bhutas (ghosts/spirits). Krishna classifies worship by guna. In 2026 terms: sattvic faith seeks wisdom/harmony (higher deities); rajasic seeks power/control (lower astral forces); tamasic seeks occult/ancestral/lower entities. This verse explains why different spiritual practices attract different results — the object of worship matches the practitioner’s guna.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अशास्त्रविहितं घोरं तप्यन्ते ये तपो जनाः |
दम्भाहङ्कारसंयुक्ताः कामरागबलान्विताः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
aśāstra-vihitaṁ ghoraṁ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ
dambhāhaṅkāra-saṁyuktāḥ kāma-rāga-balānvitāḥ
shlokas.translation: Those who undergo severe austerities and penances not mentioned in the scriptures, impelled by pride, egoism, lust and attachment to sense gratification —
shlokas.modern: People who perform extreme, unscriptural austerities driven by hypocrisy, ego, desire and passion. Krishna begins classifying austerity (tapas) by guna — first the tamasic/rajasic misuse. In practice: crash diets, punishing workouts, forced celibacy for show, extreme fasting for ego — these are not divine. Krishna is warning against spiritual bypassing and self-torture disguised as sadhana.

shlokas.sanskrit:
कर्शयन्तः शरीरस्थं भूतग्राममचेतसः |
मां चैवान्तःशरीरस्थं तान्विद्ध्यासुरनिश्चयान् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
karṣayantaḥ śarīra-sthaṁ bhūta-grāmam acetasaḥ
māṁ caivāntaḥ-śarīra-sthaṁ tān viddhy āsura-niścayān
shlokas.translation: Ignorant persons torment the material elements of the body and the Supersoul dwelling within. Such people are demonic in their resolve.
shlokas.modern: They torture the body’s elements and Me (the Supersoul within) — know them to be of demonic determination. This is Krishna’s strong verdict on misguided austerity. In practice: extreme self-denial that harms the body also harms the indwelling Divine. Krishna is saying: torturing yourself is torturing Me. This verse protects against masochistic spirituality — real tapas nourishes, not destroys.

shlokas.sanskrit:
आहारस्त्वपि सर्वस्य त्रिविधो भवति प्रियः |
यज्ञस्तपस्तथा दानं तेषां भेदमिमं शृणु ||
shlokas.transliteration:
āhāras tv api sarvasya tri-vidho bhavati priyaḥ
yajñas tapas tathā dānaṁ teṣāṁ bhedam imaṁ śṛṇu
shlokas.translation: Even food is dear to everyone in three ways according to the three modes. The same is true of sacrifices, austerities and charity. Now hear of the distinctions between them.
shlokas.modern: Food, sacrifice, austerity, charity — each is of three kinds according to the gunas. Krishna is about to classify everyday life by guna. In 2026 life: this is the ultimate audit tool — what you eat, how you worship, what you give up, how you donate — all reveal your inner constitution. Krishna is saying: nothing is neutral; everything you do is colored by sattva, rajas or tamas.

shlokas.sanskrit:
आयुःसत्त्वबलारोग्यसुखप्रीतिविवर्धनाः |
रस्याः स्निग्धाः स्थिरा हृद्या आहाराः सात्त्विकाः प्रियाः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
āyuḥ-sattva-balārogya-sukha-prīti-vivardhanāḥ
rasyāḥ snigdhāḥ sthirā hṛdyā āhārāḥ sāttvikāḥ priyāḥ
shlokas.translation: Foods dear to those in the mode of goodness increase life, purify one’s existence, give strength, health, happiness and satisfaction. Such foods are juicy, wholesome, stable and pleasing to the heart.
shlokas.modern: Sattvic foods: promote longevity, clarity, strength, health, joy, love; juicy, nourishing, steady, heart-pleasing (fresh fruits/vegetables, milk, grains, nuts, mild spices). In practice: sattvic diet = vitality + mental clarity. Krishna is giving the dietary signature of goodness — food that enlivens rather than agitates or dulls.

shlokas.sanskrit:
कट्वम्ललवणात्युष्णतीक्ष्णरूक्षविदाहिनः |
आहारा राजसस्येष्टा दुःखशोकामयप्रदाः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
kaṭv-amla-lavaṇāty-uṣṇa-tīkṣṇa-rūkṣa-vidāhinaḥ
āhārā rājasasy eṣṭā duḥkha-śokāmaya-pradāḥ
shlokas.translation: Foods that are too bitter, too sour, salty, very hot, pungent, dry and burning are dear to those in the mode of passion. Such foods cause pain, distress and disease.
shlokas.modern: Rajasic foods: overly spicy, sour, salty, hot, dry, burning — cause pain, grief, disease. In 2026 terms: fast food, excessive chili/coffee/caffeine, fried/salty snacks — stimulate then crash. Krishna links rajasic diet to agitation and eventual suffering.

shlokas.sanskrit:
यातयामं गतरसं पूति पर्युषितं च यत् |
उच्छिष्टं अपि चामेध्यं भोजनं तामसप्रियम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
yāta-yāmaṁ gata-rasaṁ pūti paryuṣitaṁ ca yat
ucchiṣṭam api cāmedhyaṁ bhojanaṁ tāmasa-priyam
shlokas.translation: Food prepared more than three hours before being eaten, tasteless, decomposed, putrid, leftover and unclean is dear to those in the mode of ignorance.
shlokas.modern: Tamasic food: stale, tasteless, rotten, leftover, impure. In practice: old food, heavily processed junk, meat (in many interpretations), anything that dulls the mind. Krishna links tamasic diet to inertia and darkness. This verse is dietary hygiene guidance — fresh, vital food supports sattva.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्यज्ञैर्विधिदृष्टो य इज्यते |
यष्टव्यमेवेति मनः समाधाय स सात्त्विकः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
aphalākāṅkṣibhir yajñair vidhi-dṛṣṭo ya ijyate
yaṣṭavyam eveti manaḥ samādhāya sa sāttvikaḥ
shlokas.translation: Of sacrifices, that sacrifice which is offered according to the directions of scripture, as a matter of duty, for the sake of the Supreme, by those without desire for fruitive results — that is in the mode of goodness.
shlokas.modern: Sattvic sacrifice: scriptural, dutiful, offered to the Supreme, without desire for reward. In practice: worship done as dharma, not for personal gain — pure offering. Krishna classifies spiritual practice by intention — even the same ritual can be sattvic or otherwise depending on motive.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अभिसंधाय तु फलं दम्भार्थमपि चैव यत् |
इज्यते भरतश्रेष्ठ तं यज्ञं विद्धि राजसम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
abhisaṁdhāya tu phalaṁ dambhārtham api caiva yat
ijyate bharata-śreṣṭha taṁ yajñaṁ viddhi rājasam
shlokas.translation: But that sacrifice performed with the hope of some material benefit, or for the sake of prestige — know that to be in the mode of passion, O chief of the Bharatas.
shlokas.modern: Rajasic sacrifice: performed for reward or show. In practice: pujas, donations, rituals done for status, results, or social approval — binding. Krishna is exposing performative spirituality — motive reveals guna.

shlokas.sanskrit:
विधिहीनमसृष्टान्नं मन्त्रहीनमदक्षिणम् |
श्रद्धाविरहितं यज्ञं तामसं परिचक्षते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
vidhi-hīnam asṛṣṭānnaṁ mantra-hīnam adakṣiṇam
śraddhā-virahitaṁ yajñaṁ tāmasaṁ paricakṣate
shlokas.translation: Any sacrifice performed without scriptural direction, without distribution of prasadam, without chanting of Vedic hymns, without offerings to the priest, and without faith — is considered to be in the mode of ignorance.
shlokas.modern: Tamasic sacrifice: without rule, no food distributed, no mantras, no dakshina, no faith. In practice: mechanical/ignorant rituals, empty ceremonies, faithless worship. Krishna is warning against soulless spirituality — when practice lacks heart and method, it is tamasic.

shlokas.sanskrit:
देवद्विजगुरुप्राज्ञपूजनं शौचमार्जवम् |
ब्रह्मचर्यमहिंसा च शारीरं तप उच्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
deva-dvija-guru-prājña-pūjanaṁ śaucam ārjavam
brahmacaryam ahiṁsā ca śārīraṁ tapa ucyate
shlokas.translation: Austerity of the body consists of worship of the Supreme Lord, the brahmanas, the spiritual master, and superiors like the father and mother, cleanliness, simplicity, celibacy and nonviolence.
shlokas.modern: Physical tapas: worship of God, brahmanas, guru, elders; purity, simplicity, celibacy (moderation), nonviolence. In practice: reverence, cleanliness, humility, sense restraint, harmlessness — these are sattvic bodily austerities. Krishna classifies tapas by guna — this is the pure form.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अनुद्वेगकरं वाक्यं सत्यं प्रियहितं च यत् |
स्वाध्यायाभ्यसनं चैव वाङ्मयं तप उच्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
anudvega-karaṁ vākyaṁ satyaṁ priya-hitaṁ ca yat
svādhyāyābhyasanaṁ caiva vāṅmayaṁ tapa ucyate
shlokas.translation: Austerity of speech consists in speaking words that are truthful, pleasing, beneficial, and not agitating to others, and also in regularly reciting Vedic literature.
shlokas.modern: Verbal tapas: speech that is true, pleasing, beneficial, non-disturbing; regular scriptural study. In practice: honest, kind, useful words + daily wisdom reading. Krishna is giving speech hygiene — sattvic communication heals and elevates. This verse is a guide for modern discourse — avoid agitation, speak truth with love.

shlokas.sanskrit:
मनःप्रसादः सौम्यत्वं मौनमात्मविनिग्रहः |
भावसंशुद्धिरिति तत् तपो मानसमुच्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
manaḥ-prasādaḥ saumyatvaṁ maunam ātma-vinigrahaḥ
bhāva-saṁśuddhir iti tat tapo mānasam ucyate
shlokas.translation: Austerity of the mind consists of satisfaction, simplicity, gravity, self-control and purification of one’s consciousness.
shlokas.modern: Mental tapas: mental cheerfulness, gentleness, silence (inner/outer), self-control, purity of feeling. In practice: calm mind, soft disposition, thoughtful restraint, emotional purity. Krishna is describing sattvic mental discipline — inner peace and clarity. This verse is mental health guidance — cultivate these for a pure mind.

shlokas.sanskrit:
श्रद्धया परया तप्तं तपस्तत्त्रिविधं नरैः |
अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्युक्तैः सात्त्विकं परिचक्षते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
śraddhayā parayā taptaṁ tapas tat tri-vidhaṁ naraiḥ
aphalākāṅkṣibhir yuktaiḥ sāttvikaṁ paricakṣate
shlokas.translation: When men of austere vows perform these three kinds of austerity with faith, without desiring fruitive results, such austerity is called in the mode of goodness.
shlokas.modern: Austerity done with supreme faith, without expecting reward — that is sattvic. Krishna classifies tapas by intention. In practice: discipline offered to the Divine, not for ego-boost or results — pure. This verse emphasizes motive — even the same practice can be sattvic or otherwise depending on why it is done.

shlokas.sanskrit:
सत्कारमानपुरस्कारं तपो दम्भेन चैव यत् |
क्रियते तदिह प्रोक्तं राजसं चलमध्रुवम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
satkāra-māna-puraṣkāraṁ tapo dambhena caiva yat
kriyate tad iha proktaṁ rājasaṁ calamadhruvam
shlokas.translation: Austerity performed out of pride and for the sake of gaining respect, honor and worship is said to be in the mode of passion. It is impermanent and unsteady.
shlokas.modern: Rajasic tapas: done for show, respect, fame — unstable and temporary. In practice: extreme practices for social media likes, guru status, admiration — binding. Krishna exposes performative austerity — it may look impressive but lacks depth and endurance.

shlokas.sanskrit:
मूढग्राहेणात्मनो यत्पीडया क्रियते तपः |
परस्योत्सादनार्थं वा तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
mūḍha-grāheṇātmano yat pīḍayā kriyate tapaḥ
parasya utsādanārthaṁ vā tat tāmasam udāhṛtam
shlokas.translation: Austerity performed out of foolishness, with self-torture or for the purpose of harming others, is said to be in the mode of ignorance.
shlokas.modern: Tamasic tapas: foolish self-harm or harming others. In practice: punishing asceticism, extreme diets for ego, black magic, curses — destructive. Krishna condemns self-torture and harmful practices — they are tamasic and demonic. This verse protects against misguided spirituality.

shlokas.sanskrit:
दातव्यमिति यद्दानं दीयतेऽनुपकारिणे |
देशे काले च पात्रे च तद्दानं सात्त्विकं स्मृतम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
dātavyam iti yad dānaṁ dīyate ’nupakāriṇe
deśe kāle ca pātre ca tad dānaṁ sāttvikam smṛtam
shlokas.translation: Charity given out of duty, without expectation of return, at the proper time and place, and to a worthy person — that is considered to be in the mode of goodness.
shlokas.modern: Sattvic charity: given because it should be given, to the deserving, at right time/place, without expecting return. In practice: generous giving without strings, to genuine need. Krishna is describing selfless philanthropy — pure giving. This is the gold standard for dāna.

shlokas.sanskrit:
यत्तु प्रत्युपकारार्थं फलमुद्दिश्य वा पुनः |
दीयते च परिक्लिष्टं तद्दानं राजसं स्मृतम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
yat tu pratyupakārārthaṁ phalam uddiśya vā punaḥ
dīyate ca parikliṣṭaṁ tad dānaṁ rājasam smṛtam
shlokas.translation: But charity performed with the expectation of some return, or with a desire for fruitive results, or given in a begrudging mood — that is said to be in the mode of passion.
shlokas.modern: Rajasic charity: given for return, reward, or grudgingly. In practice: transactional giving, 'I’ll donate if I get recognition', reluctant giving. Krishna exposes conditional generosity — it binds the giver. This verse is a mirror for modern philanthropy — motive matters.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अदेशकाले यद्दानमपात्रेभ्यश्च दीयते |
असत्कृतमवज्ञातं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
adeśa-kāle yad dānam apātrebhyaś ca dīyate
asatkṛtam avajñātaṁ tat tāmasam udāhṛtam
shlokas.translation: And charity performed at an improper time and place, to unworthy persons, without respect and with insult — that is said to be in the mode of ignorance.
shlokas.modern: Tamasic charity: wrong time/place, to undeserving, disrespectfully or insultingly. In practice: throwing money at wrong causes, giving with contempt, careless donation. Krishna is showing how even 'giving' can degrade when done in tamas. This verse warns against mindless or spiteful charity.

shlokas.sanskrit:
ॐ तत्सदिति निर्देशो ब्रह्मणस्त्रिविधः स्मृतः |
ब्राह्मणास्तेन वेदाश्च यज्ञाश्च विहिताः पुरा ||
shlokas.transliteration:
oṁ tat sad iti nirdeśo brahmaṇas tri-vidhaḥ smṛtaḥ
brāhmaṇās tena vedāś ca yajñāś ca vihitāḥ purā
shlokas.translation: From the beginning of creation, the three words om tat sat were used to indicate the Supreme Absolute Truth. From them came the priests, the scriptures and sacrifice.
shlokas.modern: OM TAT SAT — the three-fold designation of Brahman from the beginning. From these came brahmanas, Vedas, and sacrifice. Krishna introduces the sacred utterance. In practice: these three syllables sanctify all spiritual acts. This verse sets up the final classification — how OM TAT SAT purifies action according to guna.

shlokas.sanskrit:
तस्मादोमित्युदाहृत्य यज्ञदानतपःक्रियाः |
प्रवर्तन्ते विधानोक्ताः सततं ब्रह्मवादिनाम् ||
shlokas.transliteration:
tasmād om ity udāhṛtya yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ
pravartante vidhānoktāḥ satataṁ brahma-vādinām
shlokas.translation: Therefore, all sacrifices, charities and penances are begun with the utterance of om by the transcendentalists who study the Vedas.
shlokas.modern: All Vedic acts — sacrifice, charity, austerity — are started with OM by those who know Brahman. In practice: OM sanctifies and aligns action with the Supreme. Krishna is giving the ritual key — begin with OM to make any practice sattvic.

shlokas.sanskrit:
तदित्यनभिसंधाय फलं यज्ञतपःक्रियाः |
दानक्रियाश्च विविधाः क्रियन्ते मोक्षकाङ्क्षिभिः ||
shlokas.transliteration:
tad ity anabhisandhāya phalaṁ yajña-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ
dāna-kriyāś ca vividhāḥ kriyante mokṣa-kāṅkṣibhiḥ
shlokas.translation: With the utterance of tat, without consideration of fruitive results, sacrifices, austerities and various acts of charity are performed by those who desire liberation.
shlokas.modern: With TAT, those seeking liberation perform sacrifice, austerity, charity without attachment to results. In practice: TAT indicates renunciation of fruit — action offered without desire for return. Krishna is showing how the syllable purifies motive — detachment + devotion.

shlokas.sanskrit:
सद्भावे साधुभावे च सदित्येतत्प्रयुज्यते |
प्रशस्ते कर्मणि तथा सच्छब्दः पार्थ युज्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration:
sad-bhāve sādhu-bhāve ca sad ity etat prayujyate
praśaste karmaṇi tathā sac-chabdaḥ pārtha yujyate
shlokas.translation: The word sat is used in the sense of existence and goodness, and is also used to describe an auspicious activity, O son of Pritha.
shlokas.modern: SAT means existence, goodness, and is used for praiseworthy actions. In practice: SAT affirms reality, virtue, and auspiciousness. Krishna is explaining the triple power of OM TAT SAT — aligning action with truth, goodness, and the Divine.

shlokas.sanskrit:
अश्रद्धया हुतं दत्तं तपस्तप्तं कृतं च यत् |
असदित्युच्यते पार्थ न च तत्प्रेत्य नो इह ||
shlokas.transliteration:
aśraddhayā hutaṁ dattaṁ tapas taptaṁ kṛtaṁ ca yat
asad ity ucyate pārtha na ca tat pretya no iha
shlokas.translation: Anything sacrificed, given or performed, and any austerity practiced without faith is called asat, O son of Pritha. It is useless both in this life and the next.
shlokas.modern: Any sacrifice, charity, austerity done without faith is called asat — useless here and hereafter. Krishna ends with a strong warning. In practice: faith (śraddhā) is the life-force of any spiritual act — without it, nothing bears fruit. This verse is the chapter’s final diagnostic — sincerity/faith is the ultimate qualifier. Even the best action without heart is empty.
